author: bridge-bot
content: <frozenfire89> Is there a way that contributors could have their contribution to Tau be split into user-provided and device-sourced entropy, in such a way that the contributor can later verify that their user-provided entropy is present in the contribution that the coordinator has included, without disclosing (or knowing) the entirety of their contribution entropy?

author: bridge-bot
content: <frozenfire89> And, is there a way that the contributor can include that user-provided entropy without supplying it directly to the ceremony client? (e.g. performing an operation in another unconnected tool)

author: ralexstokes
content: what would this add that justifies the extra complexity to support the use case ?

author: bridge-bot
content: <frozenfire89> > <frozenfire89>  Having user-provided entropy in the contribution would allow the user to verify that their contribution's entropy wasn't decided by compromised ceremony client software, or a compromised RNG. But, having the device-sourced entropy would also mean that the contributor isn't saving their toxic waste entirely. (re @kzg_ceremony_bot: <ralexstokes> what would this add that justifies the extra complexity to support the use case ?)

author: bridge-bot
content: <frozenfire89> Contributors currently don't have a way to actually audit the security of their contribution deeply. They have to trust the ceremony client they're using, and have to trust their hardware and operating system as well.

author: bridge-bot
content: <frozenfire89> If the contributor can also apply their user-provided entropy externally to the client, they can also prevent the client from exfiltrating that component of their contribution.

author: bridge-bot
content: <Barrywhitehat> Seems there is no way to be sure a client contributed the randomness except making a ZKP of the contribution. Which i think is a good idea but definitely should be outside the scope of the basic UI as its a lot of complexity

author: bridge-bot
content: <Barrywhitehat> I would be very excited to see a team working on this tho
